page.title: 09FAST FLOWING RIVER ARUN
page.content: The Arun is the second fastest river after the Severn. The banks have been re-inforced in many parts to avoid the extensive flooding which at times would turn the valley into an inland sea. Two meanders in the river gap make islands accessible by simple bridges so that cows can graze on the rich grass. Weed grows extensively in the water, and rushes line the banks. Coarse fishing in the river is good and many clubs and syndicates rent stretches of the banks. Motor boats speed up and down the main river and larger launches take visitors for trips. Sometimes one may be lucky enough to see a kingfisher. Swans and their cygnets abound as well as moorhens and coots.
